output: Hypertension, commonly known as high blood pressure, is a chronic medical condition where the force of blood against artery walls is consistently too high. Normal blood pressure is typically below 120/80 mmHg, while hypertension is diagnosed when readings consistently exceed 140/90 mmHg. It's often called the 'silent killer' because it usually has no symptoms but can lead to serious complications like heart disease, stroke, and kidney damage if left untreated.

output: Type 2 diabetes mellitus is a chronic metabolic disorder characterized by insulin resistance and relative insulin deficiency. The body either doesn't produce enough insulin or cannot effectively use the insulin it produces, leading to elevated blood glucose levels. This condition typically develops in adults and is often associated with obesity, sedentary lifestyle, and genetic factors. Management includes lifestyle modifications, medication, and blood sugar monitoring.

Metformin is a first-line oral medication for treating type 2 diabetes. It belongs to the biguanide class of drugs and works primarily by reducing glucose production in the liver and improving insulin sensitivity in muscle tissues. It also helps decrease glucose absorption in the intestines. Common side effects include gastrointestinal upset, and it's contraindicated in patients with kidney disease due to risk of lactic acidosis.

Hypertension is a cardiovascular condition where blood pressure in the arteries is persistently elevated above normal levels. It occurs when the heart pumps blood with excessive force or when arteries become narrow or stiff. Risk factors include age, family history, obesity, excessive salt intake, lack of physical activity, and stress. Treatment typically involves lifestyle changes and antihypertensive medications to prevent complications like heart attack, stroke, and kidney disease.

Diabetes is a group of metabolic disorders characterized by chronically elevated blood glucose levels due to defects in insulin production, insulin action, or both. The main types are Type 1 (autoimmune destruction of insulin-producing cells), Type 2 (insulin resistance and relative insulin deficiency), and gestational diabetes. Symptoms include excessive thirst, frequent urination, unexplained weight loss, fatigue, and blurred vision. Long-term complications can affect the eyes, kidneys, nerves, and cardiovascular system.

Asthma is a chronic respiratory disease characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways, leading to difficulty breathing. During an asthma attack, the muscles around the airways tighten, the lining becomes inflamed and swollen, and excess mucus is produced. Common triggers include allergens, exercise, cold air, respiratory infections, and stress. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Treatment involves avoiding triggers and using bronchodilators and anti-inflammatory medications.

Anemia is a condition where the blood has fewer red blood cells than normal or the red blood cells don't contain enough hemoglobin to carry adequate oxygen to body tissues. Common types include iron-deficiency anemia, vitamin B12 deficiency anemia, and chronic disease anemia. Symptoms include fatigue, weakness, pale skin, shortness of breath, dizziness, and cold hands and feet. Treatment depends on the underlying cause and may include dietary changes, supplements, or addressing underlying conditions.

Migraine is a neurological disorder characterized by recurrent, severe headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. The pain is typically throbbing or pulsating and usually affects one side of the head. Migraines can last from hours to days and may be preceded by visual disturbances called auras. Triggers can include stress, certain foods, hormonal changes, sleep disturbances, and environmental factors. Treatment includes preventive medications, acute pain relief, and lifestyle modifications.

Arthritis refers to inflammation of one or more joints, causing pain, stiffness, swelling, and reduced range of motion. The two most common types are osteoarthritis (wear-and-tear arthritis affecting cartilage) and rheumatoid arthritis (autoimmune condition affecting joint lining). Symptoms worsen with age and can significantly impact daily activities. Treatment includes medications to reduce inflammation and pain, physical therapy, lifestyle modifications, and in severe cases, joint replacement surgery.

Osteoporosis is a bone disease characterized by decreased bone density and deterioration of bone tissue, leading to increased fracture risk. Bones become porous, weak, and brittle, resembling a honeycomb structure. It's more common in postmenopausal women due to estrogen deficiency, but can also affect men and younger individuals. Risk factors include age, family history, smoking, excessive alcohol consumption, and certain medications. Prevention and treatment involve calcium and vitamin D supplementation, weight-bearing exercise, and medications to strengthen bones.

Pneumonia is an infection that causes inflammation in the air sacs (alveoli) of one or both lungs. The air sacs may fill with fluid or pus, causing cough with phlegm, fever, chills, and difficulty breathing. It can be caused by bacteria, viruses, fungi, or other microorganisms. Bacterial pneumonia is often more severe, while viral pneumonia is usually milder. Risk factors include age, weakened immune system, chronic diseases, and smoking. Treatment depends on the cause and may include antibiotics, antivirals, rest, and supportive care.

Tuberculosis (TB) is a potentially serious infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria that primarily affects the lungs but can also affect other parts of the body. It spreads through airborne droplets when infected individuals cough, sneeze, or speak. Symptoms include persistent cough lasting more than three weeks, chest pain, coughing up blood, weight loss, fever, and night sweats. TB can be latent (inactive) or active (contagious). Treatment requires a long course of multiple antibiotics, typically lasting 6-9 months.

Epilepsy is a neurological disorder characterized by recurrent, unprovoked seizures due to abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Seizures can vary from brief lapses of attention to severe convulsions and can affect consciousness, movement, and behavior. Types include focal seizures (affecting one area of the brain) and generalized seizures (affecting the entire brain). Causes can include genetic factors, brain injuries, infections, or developmental disorders. Treatment primarily involves antiepileptic medications, and in some cases, surgery or other therapies may be considered.

An allergy is an immune system reaction to a substance that is typically harmless to most people. When exposed to an allergen, the immune system overreacts and produces antibodies called IgE, triggering the release of histamine and other chemicals. Common allergens include pollen, dust mites, pet dander, certain foods, medications, and insect stings. Symptoms can range from mild (sneezing, itching, rash) to severe (anaphylaxis, a life-threatening reaction). Treatment includes avoiding allergens, antihistamines, corticosteroids, and in severe cases, epinephrine.

Thyroid disorders involve dysfunction of the thyroid gland, which produces hormones that regulate metabolism, growth, and development. Common disorders include hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid causing fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance) and hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid causing weight loss, rapid heartbeat, anxiety). Other conditions include goiter (enlarged thyroid), thyroid nodules, and thyroid cancer. Diagnosis involves blood tests measuring thyroid hormone levels (TSH, T3, T4). Treatment varies depending on the specific condition and may include hormone replacement therapy, medications, or surgery.

COVID-19 is an infectious disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus, first identified in 2019. It primarily spreads through respiratory droplets and can cause a wide range of symptoms from mild cold-like symptoms to severe respiratory illness. Common symptoms include fever, cough, shortness of breath, fatigue, body aches, loss of taste or smell, and sore throat. Severe cases can lead to pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and multi-organ failure. Prevention includes vaccination, wearing masks, social distancing, and good hand hygiene. Treatment varies based on severity and may include supportive care, antivirals, and monoclonal antibodies.

AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome) is the final stage of HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) infection, characterized by severe immune system damage. HIV attacks CD4+ T cells, weakening the body's ability to fight infections and certain cancers. AIDS is diagnosed when CD4+ cell count falls below 200 cells/mm³ or when certain opportunistic infections occur. Without treatment, HIV typically progresses to AIDS within 8-10 years. Modern antiretroviral therapy (ART) can prevent progression to AIDS, allowing people with HIV to live near-normal lifespans while reducing transmission risk to nearly zero.

Gastroenteritis is inflammation of the stomach and intestines, commonly called 'stomach flu' though it's not related to influenza. It's typically caused by viral, bacterial, or parasitic infections, contaminated food or water, or certain medications. Symptoms include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach cramps, fever, and dehydration. Most cases are mild and resolve within a few days with rest and fluid replacement. Severe cases may require medical attention, especially in young children, elderly, or immunocompromised individuals. Prevention includes proper hand hygiene, food safety, and avoiding contaminated water.

Bronchitis is inflammation of the bronchial tubes that carry air to the lungs. Acute bronchitis is usually caused by viral infections and lasts a few weeks, while chronic bronchitis is a long-term condition often caused by smoking and is part of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Symptoms include persistent cough with mucus, shortness of breath, chest discomfort, fatigue, and low-grade fever. Acute bronchitis usually resolves on its own with rest and supportive care, while chronic bronchitis requires ongoing management including bronchodilators, anti-inflammatory medications, and lifestyle changes.

Eczema, also known as atopic dermatitis, is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by dry, itchy, and inflamed skin. It often begins in childhood and can persist into adulthood. The exact cause is unknown but involves genetic factors, immune system dysfunction, and environmental triggers. Symptoms include red, scaly patches, intense itching, and sometimes oozing or crusting. Common triggers include allergens, irritants, stress, weather changes, and certain fabrics. Treatment includes moisturizers, topical corticosteroids, antihistamines, and avoiding known triggers. Severe cases may require systemic medications or phototherapy.

Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral infection transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, common in tropical and subtropical regions. The dengue virus has four distinct serotypes, and infection with one type provides immunity to that type but increases risk of severe disease if infected with a different type later. Symptoms include sudden onset of high fever, severe headache, eye pain, muscle and joint pain, and skin rash. Severe dengue can cause plasma leakage, bleeding, and organ dysfunction. There's no specific treatment, so management focuses on symptom relief and fluid management. Prevention involves mosquito control and vaccination in endemic areas.

Lupus is a chronic autoimmune disease where the immune system attacks the body's own tissues and organs, causing widespread inflammation. The most common form is systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which can affect skin, joints, kidneys, heart, lungs, and brain. Symptoms include fatigue, joint pain, skin rashes (including the characteristic butterfly rash across the cheeks), fever, and organ-specific symptoms. The disease often follows a pattern of flares and remissions. Diagnosis involves blood tests for specific antibodies and clinical criteria. Treatment includes immunosuppressive medications, corticosteroids, and lifestyle modifications to manage symptoms and prevent organ damage.

Poliomyelitis (polio) is a highly infectious viral disease caused by poliovirus that primarily affects young children. The virus invades the nervous system and can cause paralysis within hours. Most infections are asymptomatic or cause mild flu-like symptoms, but in some cases, the virus attacks nerve cells controlling muscles, leading to paralysis, particularly of the legs. Severe cases can affect breathing muscles, requiring mechanical ventilation. Thanks to widespread vaccination, polio has been eradicated in most countries, with only Afghanistan and Pakistan still reporting cases. The condition has no cure, but it's entirely preventable through vaccination.

Alzheimer's disease is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder and the most common cause of dementia. It's characterized by the accumulation of amyloid plaques and tau tangles in the brain, leading to neuron death and brain shrinkage. Symptoms begin with mild memory loss and progress to severe cognitive decline, including confusion, disorientation, mood changes, and eventually loss of ability to carry out daily activities. Risk factors include age, genetics, cardiovascular disease, and lifestyle factors. While there's no cure, medications can temporarily slow symptom progression, and lifestyle interventions may help reduce risk. Research continues into disease-modifying treatments.

Kidney stones are hard deposits of minerals and salts that form inside the kidneys. They develop when urine becomes concentrated, allowing minerals to crystallize and stick together. Common types include calcium stones, uric acid stones, struvite stones, and cystine stones. Symptoms include severe pain in the side and back, pain during urination, blood in urine, nausea, and frequent urination. Small stones may pass naturally with increased fluid intake, while larger stones may require medical intervention such as shock wave lithotripsy, ureteroscopy, or surgery. Prevention includes staying hydrated, dietary modifications, and sometimes medications.

Cancer is a group of diseases characterized by the uncontrolled growth and spread of abnormal cells. Normal cells grow, divide, and die in an orderly fashion, but cancer cells continue to divide uncontrollably and can invade nearby tissues and spread to other parts of the body through blood and lymph systems (metastasis). There are over 100 types of cancer, named after the organs or tissues where they form. Causes include genetic mutations, environmental factors, lifestyle choices, and infections. Treatment options include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, immunotherapy, and targeted therapy, often used in combination. Early detection significantly improves treatment outcomes.

Rabies is a fatal viral disease that affects the central nervous system of mammals, including humans. It's typically transmitted through the bite or scratch of an infected animal, with dogs being the most common source worldwide. The virus travels through nerves to the brain, causing inflammation and eventual death if left untreated. Symptoms progress through phases: initial flu-like symptoms, followed by neurological symptoms including anxiety, confusion, agitation, hallucinations, hypersalivation, and hydrophobia (fear of water). Once symptoms appear, the disease is almost always fatal. However, prompt post-exposure prophylaxis (rabies vaccine and immunoglobulin) is highly effective in preventing the disease.

Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) is a functional gastrointestinal disorder characterized by chronic abdominal pain and altered bowel habits without structural abnormalities. Symptoms include cramping, bloating, gas, diarrhea, and/or constipation. IBS is classified into subtypes based on predominant bowel habits: IBS-D (diarrhea-predominant), IBS-C (constipation-predominant), and IBS-M (mixed). The exact cause is unknown but involves gut-brain axis dysfunction, altered gut microbiome, and increased intestinal sensitivity. Triggers include stress, certain foods, hormonal changes, and infections. Treatment includes dietary modifications (low-FODMAP diet), stress management, probiotics, and medications to manage specific symptoms.

Insomnia is a sleep disorder characterized by difficulty falling asleep, staying asleep, or waking up too early and not being able to return to sleep. It can be acute (short-term) or chronic (lasting three months or longer). Symptoms include daytime fatigue, irritability, difficulty concentrating, and impaired performance. Causes include stress, anxiety, depression, medical conditions, medications, poor sleep habits, and environmental factors. Treatment approaches include sleep hygiene education, cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I), relaxation techniques, and sometimes sleep medications. Addressing underlying causes and establishing consistent sleep routines are crucial for long-term management.

A cataract is a clouding of the eye's natural lens, which lies behind the iris and pupil. This clouding blocks or changes the passage of light into the eye, causing vision problems. Cataracts are most commonly related to aging but can also result from injury, certain medications, diseases like diabetes, or prolonged exposure to ultraviolet light. Symptoms include blurry vision, increased sensitivity to light and glare, seeing halos around lights, and faded or yellowed colors. Cataracts develop slowly and may not initially affect vision significantly. Treatment involves surgical removal of the clouded lens and replacement with an artificial intraocular lens, which is highly successful in restoring vision.

Meningitis is inflammation of the protective membranes (meninges) covering the brain and spinal cord. It can be caused by bacterial, viral, fungal, or parasitic infections, with bacterial meningitis being the most serious form. Symptoms include sudden onset of fever, headache, neck stiffness, nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light, confusion, and sometimes a distinctive rash. Bacterial meningitis is a medical emergency requiring immediate antibiotic treatment to prevent brain damage, hearing loss, or death. Viral meningitis is usually less severe and often resolves on its own. Vaccination is available for some types of bacterial meningitis, including meningococcal and pneumococcal vaccines.

A urinary tract infection (UTI) is an infection in any part of the urinary system, including kidneys, bladder, ureters, and urethra. Most UTIs involve the lower urinary tract (bladder and urethra). UTIs are more common in women due to their shorter urethra. Symptoms include a strong, persistent urge to urinate, burning sensation during urination, cloudy or strong-smelling urine, pelvic pain in women, and sometimes blood in urine. Most UTIs are caused by bacteria, particularly E. coli from the intestinal tract. Treatment typically involves antibiotics, and prevention includes proper hygiene, adequate hydration, and urinating after sexual activity.

Parkinson's disease is a progressive neurological disorder that affects movement, caused by the loss of dopamine-producing brain cells in the substantia nigra. The four main symptoms are tremor (especially at rest), rigidity (muscle stiffness), bradykinesia (slowness of movement), and postural instability. Non-motor symptoms can include depression, anxiety, sleep disorders, and cognitive changes. The exact cause is unknown but involves genetic and environmental factors. Diagnosis is primarily clinical, based on symptoms and response to dopamine medication. Treatment includes levodopa and other medications to manage symptoms, physical therapy, and in advanced cases, deep brain stimulation surgery. While there's no cure, treatments can significantly improve quality of life.

Influenza (flu) is a contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses that infect the nose, throat, and sometimes the lungs. It's characterized by sudden onset of fever, cough, sore throat, body aches, headache, chills, and fatigue. Influenza viruses are classified into types A, B, and C, with A and B causing seasonal epidemics. The virus spreads through droplets when infected people cough, sneeze, or talk. Complications can include pneumonia, particularly in high-risk groups like young children, adults over 65, pregnant women, and people with chronic conditions. Annual vaccination is the best prevention method, and antiviral medications can reduce severity and duration if taken early.

A stroke occurs when blood flow to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, depriving brain tissue of oxygen and nutrients. There are two main types: ischemic stroke (caused by blocked blood vessels, accounting for 87% of strokes) and hemorrhagic stroke (caused by bleeding in the brain). Symptoms include sudden numbness or weakness (especially on one side), confusion, trouble speaking or understanding speech, vision problems, severe headache, and loss of balance. The acronym FAST (Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call emergency services) helps identify stroke symptoms. Immediate medical treatment is crucial to minimize brain damage and potential complications.

Measles is a highly contagious viral infection caused by the measles virus (rubeola). It spreads through respiratory droplets and is so contagious that 90% of susceptible people exposed to it will become infected. Symptoms begin with fever, cough, runny nose, and red, watery eyes, followed by a characteristic red, blotchy rash that starts on the face and spreads downward. Complications can include ear infections, pneumonia, encephalitis, and death, particularly in children under 5, adults over 20, and immunocompromised individuals. Measles is entirely preventable through vaccination with the MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine. Thanks to widespread vaccination, measles has been eliminated in many countries.

Depression is a common mental health disorder characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and loss of interest in activities once enjoyed. Symptoms include changes in appetite and sleep patterns, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, feelings of worthlessness or guilt, and sometimes thoughts of death or suicide. Major depressive disorder can significantly impair daily functioning and quality of life. Causes involve a complex interaction of genetic, biological, environmental, and psychological factors. Treatment typically includes psychotherapy (such as cognitive-behavioral therapy), medications (antidepressants), lifestyle changes, and sometimes other interventions like electroconvulsive therapy for severe cases. With proper treatment, most people with depression can recover and lead fulfilling lives.

Cholesterol is a waxy, fat-like substance found in all cells of the body and in many foods. While the body needs some cholesterol to function properly, too much can lead to health problems. There are two main types: low-density lipoprotein (LDL or 'bad' cholesterol) and high-density lipoprotein (HDL or 'good' cholesterol). High levels of LDL cholesterol can build up in artery walls, forming plaques that narrow and harden arteries (atherosclerosis), increasing risk of heart disease and stroke. HDL cholesterol helps remove LDL cholesterol from arteries. Management includes dietary changes, exercise, weight control, and sometimes medications like statins to lower cholesterol levels.

Obesity is a medical condition characterized by excess body fat that increases the risk of health problems. It's typically defined by body mass index (BMI), with a BMI of 30 or higher indicating obesity. Obesity results from a complex interaction of genetic, behavioral, and environmental factors, fundamentally involving an imbalance between calories consumed and calories expended. Health complications include type 2 diabetes, heart disease, stroke, sleep apnea, certain cancers, and osteoarthritis. Treatment approaches include lifestyle modifications (diet and exercise), behavioral therapy, medications, and in severe cases, bariatric surgery. Prevention focuses on maintaining a healthy diet, regular physical activity, and lifestyle habits that promote healthy weight.

Chickenpox is a highly contagious viral infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus, primarily affecting children but can occur in adults. It's characterized by an itchy rash with small, fluid-filled blisters that eventually crust over. The rash typically starts on the chest, back, and face before spreading to the entire body. Other symptoms include fever, headache, and fatigue. The disease is usually mild in healthy children but can be more severe in adults, infants, and immunocompromised individuals. Complications can include bacterial skin infections, pneumonia, and encephalitis. Chickenpox is preventable through vaccination, and once infected, most people develop lifelong immunity, though the virus can reactivate later as shingles.

Vertigo is a sensation of spinning or dizziness, often described as feeling like you or your surroundings are moving when they're not. It's a symptom of various underlying conditions affecting the inner ear or brain. The most common cause is benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), caused by calcium particles in the inner ear canals. Other causes include vestibular neuritis, Ménière's disease, and migraines. Symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, sweating, and balance problems. Episodes can last from minutes to hours. Treatment depends on the underlying cause and may include repositioning maneuvers (like the Epley maneuver), medications to reduce nausea and dizziness, and vestibular rehabilitation therapy.

Tonsillitis is inflammation of the tonsils, two oval-shaped lymphoid tissues located at the back of the throat. It can be caused by viral or bacterial infections, with streptococcal bacteria being a common bacterial cause. Symptoms include sore throat, difficulty swallowing, swollen and red tonsils (sometimes with white or yellow patches), fever, swollen lymph nodes, and bad breath. Viral tonsillitis usually resolves on its own with supportive care, while bacterial tonsillitis requires antibiotic treatment. Recurrent tonsillitis may require tonsillectomy (surgical removal of tonsils). Complications can include abscess formation, rheumatic fever (with streptococcal infections), and kidney problems.

Gout is a form of inflammatory arthritis caused by the buildup of uric acid crystals in joints, most commonly affecting the big toe. It occurs when the body produces too much uric acid or doesn't eliminate it efficiently, leading to hyperuricemia. Acute gout attacks cause sudden, severe pain, swelling, redness, and warmth in the affected joint, often occurring at night. Risk factors include genetics, diet high in purines (found in red meat, seafood, alcohol), obesity, kidney disease, and certain medications. Chronic gout can lead to joint damage and kidney stones. Treatment includes medications to reduce inflammation during acute attacks, drugs to lower uric acid levels, and lifestyle modifications including dietary changes and weight management.

A fracture is a medical term for a broken bone, occurring when more force is applied to a bone than it can withstand. Fractures can be classified as simple (closed) where the skin remains intact, or compound (open) where the bone breaks through the skin. They can also be complete (bone breaks completely) or incomplete (partial break). Common types include stress fractures (from repetitive force), compression fractures (from crushing force), and pathological fractures (from disease weakening the bone). Symptoms include pain, swelling, deformity, inability to use the affected area, and sometimes visible bone. Treatment depends on the type and location of fracture and may include immobilization with casts, surgical repair with plates or screws, and rehabilitation.

Fibromyalgia is a chronic disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. The condition amplifies painful sensations by affecting how the brain and spinal cord process pain signals. Symptoms include tender points throughout the body, chronic fatigue, sleep disturbances, cognitive difficulties ('fibro fog'), headaches, and mood disorders. The exact cause is unknown but may involve genetics, infections, physical or emotional trauma, and stress. Diagnosis is based on clinical criteria as there are no specific laboratory tests. Treatment is multidisciplinary, including medications (pain relievers, antidepressants, anti-seizure drugs), exercise, stress management, and cognitive-behavioral therapy.

Cirrhosis is a late stage of scarring (fibrosis) of the liver caused by many forms of liver diseases and conditions. As healthy liver tissue is destroyed and replaced by scar tissue, the liver becomes unable to function properly. Common causes include chronic alcohol abuse, hepatitis B and C infections, fatty liver disease, and autoimmune liver diseases. Early cirrhosis may have no symptoms, but as it progresses, symptoms include fatigue, weakness, weight loss, nausea, abdominal pain, spider-like blood vessels on the skin, and yellowing of skin and eyes (jaundice). Complications can include portal hypertension, ascites (fluid in abdomen), bleeding varices, and liver failure. Treatment focuses on preventing further liver damage and managing complications.

A hernia occurs when an organ or tissue pushes through a weak spot in the surrounding muscle or connective tissue. The most common types are inguinal hernias (in the groin), umbilical hernias (at the navel), and hiatal hernias (where the stomach pushes up through the diaphragm). Symptoms may include a visible bulge, pain or discomfort (especially when bending, coughing, or lifting), and a heavy or dragging sensation in the groin. Some hernias may be asymptomatic. Risk factors include aging, chronic cough, obesity, pregnancy, and previous surgery. Treatment depends on the size and symptoms but often requires surgical repair to prevent complications like strangulation (blood supply cut off) or obstruction.

Ringworm is a common fungal infection of the skin, despite its name having nothing to do with worms. It's caused by various species of fungi called dermatophytes that live on the skin, hair, and nails. The infection creates circular, red, scaly patches with raised borders and clearer centers, resembling a ring. It can affect different parts of the body: scalp (tinea capitis), body (tinea corporis), feet (athlete's foot), groin (jock itch), and nails (onychomycosis). Ringworm is highly contagious and spreads through direct contact with infected people, animals, or contaminated objects. Treatment typically involves topical or oral antifungal medications, and prevention includes good hygiene and avoiding sharing personal items.

Sinusitis is inflammation or infection of the tissue lining the sinuses, the hollow spaces in the bones around the nose, cheeks, eyes, and forehead. It can be acute (lasting less than 4 weeks), subacute (4-12 weeks), or chronic (lasting more than 12 weeks). Common causes include viral infections, bacterial infections, allergies, nasal polyps, and deviated septum. Symptoms include facial pain or pressure, nasal congestion, thick nasal discharge, reduced sense of smell, cough, and sometimes fever. Acute sinusitis often follows a cold and may resolve on its own, while chronic sinusitis.

Sinusitis is inflammation or infection of the tissue lining the sinuses, the hollow spaces in the bones around the nose, cheeks, eyes, and forehead. It can be acute (lasting less than 4 weeks), subacute (4-12 weeks), or chronic (lasting more than 12 weeks). Common causes include viral infections, bacterial infections, allergies, nasal polyps, and deviated septum. Symptoms include facial pain or pressure, nasal congestion, thick nasal discharge, reduced sense of smell, cough, and sometimes fever. Acute sinusitis often follows a cold and may resolve on its own, while chronic sinusitis requires ongoing management with medications, nasal irrigation, and sometimes surgery.

An ulcer is an open sore or lesion that develops on the skin or mucous membranes. Peptic ulcers are the most common type, occurring in the stomach (gastric ulcers) or first part of the small intestine (duodenal ulcers). They're primarily caused by Helicobacter pylori bacteria infection or prolonged use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Symptoms include burning stomach pain, bloating, heartburn, nausea, and sometimes bleeding. Complications can include perforation, obstruction, and severe bleeding. Treatment involves antibiotics for H. pylori infection, acid-reducing medications, and lifestyle modifications. Most ulcers heal completely with proper treatment.

Malaria is a life-threatening parasitic disease transmitted through the bites of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes. It's caused by Plasmodium parasites, with P. falciparum being the most deadly species. The parasites multiply in the liver and then infect red blood cells. Symptoms include fever, chills, headache, nausea, vomiting, and fatigue, typically appearing 10-15 days after infection. Severe malaria can cause organ failure, severe anemia, and cerebral malaria. It's endemic in tropical and subtropical regions, particularly sub-Saharan Africa. Prevention includes antimalarial medications, insecticide-treated bed nets, and mosquito control. Treatment involves antimalarial drugs, with prompt treatment being crucial for survival.

Hepatitis is inflammation of the liver, most commonly caused by viral infections but can also result from alcohol abuse, toxins, medications, or autoimmune diseases. The main types are Hepatitis A (spread through contaminated food/water), Hepatitis B (spread through blood and bodily fluids), and Hepatitis C (primarily spread through blood contact). Symptoms include fatigue, nausea, abdominal pain, dark urine, pale stools, and jaundice (yellowing of skin and eyes). Acute hepatitis may resolve on its own, while chronic forms (B and C) can lead to cirrhosis and liver cancer. Vaccines are available for Hepatitis A and B, and effective treatments exist for Hepatitis B and C.

Acne is a common skin condition that occurs when hair follicles become clogged with oil (sebum) and dead skin cells. It primarily affects areas with dense sebaceous glands like the face, chest, and back. Factors contributing to acne include hormonal changes (especially during puberty), genetics, certain medications, and diet. Types range from blackheads and whiteheads to inflammatory papules, pustules, and severe cystic acne. While not life-threatening, acne can cause significant emotional distress and scarring. Treatment options include topical medications (retinoids, benzoyl peroxide, antibiotics), oral medications (antibiotics, hormonal therapy, isotretinoin), and various procedures like chemical peels and laser therapy.

Gallstones are hardened deposits of digestive fluid that form in the gallbladder, a small organ beneath the liver that stores bile. They can be as small as a grain of sand or as large as a golf ball. There are two main types: cholesterol stones (most common) and pigment stones (made of bilirubin). Many people with gallstones have no symptoms, but when stones block bile ducts, they can cause sudden, intense abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and jaundice. Risk factors include obesity, rapid weight loss, high-fat diet, diabetes, and being female. Treatment ranges from watchful waiting for asymptomatic stones to surgical removal of the gallbladder (cholecystectomy) for symptomatic cases.

Zika virus is a mosquito-borne flavivirus primarily transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, the same species that spreads dengue and chikungunya. Most people infected with Zika virus have no symptoms or only mild symptoms including fever, rash, joint pain, and red eyes. However, Zika infection during pregnancy can cause serious birth defects, including microcephaly (abnormally small head and brain). It can also be sexually transmitted and has been linked to Guillain-Barré syndrome, a rare neurological condition. There's no specific treatment or vaccine for Zika virus. Prevention focuses on avoiding mosquito bites through repellents, protective clothing, and eliminating mosquito breeding sites.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system, where the immune system attacks the protective covering (myelin) of nerve fibers, causing communication problems between the brain and the rest of the body. This leads to inflammation, scarring, and damage to nerve fibers. Symptoms vary widely but can include fatigue, difficulty walking, numbness, muscle weakness, vision problems, and cognitive changes. There are four main types: relapsing-remitting, secondary-progressive, primary-progressive, and progressive-relapsing. While there's no cure, disease-modifying therapies can slow progression and manage symptoms. Physical therapy, occupational therapy, and lifestyle modifications also play important roles in management.

HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) is a virus that attacks the body's immune system, specifically CD4+ T cells, which are crucial for fighting infections. If left untreated, HIV can lead to AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome). HIV is transmitted through contact with infected blood, semen, vaginal fluids, rectal fluids, and breast milk. Common transmission routes include unprotected sexual contact, sharing needles, and from mother to child during pregnancy, childbirth, or breastfeeding. Early HIV infection may cause flu-like symptoms, but many people remain asymptomatic for years. Modern antiretroviral therapy (ART) can suppress the virus to undetectable levels, allowing people with HIV to live near-normal lifespans and preventing transmission to others.

Tetanus is a serious bacterial infection caused by Clostridium tetani, which produces a toxin that affects the nervous system, causing severe muscle spasms and contractions. The bacteria are commonly found in soil, dust, and animal feces and enter the body through wounds, cuts, or puncture injuries. Symptoms include jaw cramping (lockjaw), painful muscle spasms, difficulty swallowing, and rigid abdominal muscles. Severe cases can cause breathing difficulties, bone fractures from muscle spasms, and death. Tetanus is entirely preventable through vaccination with the tetanus toxoid, typically given as part of the DTaP or Tdap vaccines. Treatment involves wound care, antibiotics, tetanus immunoglobulin, and supportive care in intensive care settings.

Scoliosis is a sideways curvature of the spine that most often occurs during the growth spurt just before puberty. While the spine naturally has curves when viewed from the side, scoliosis involves abnormal lateral (side-to-side) curvature, often forming an 'S' or 'C' shape when viewed from behind. Most cases are idiopathic (unknown cause), but it can also result from conditions like cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy, or birth defects. Symptoms may include uneven shoulders, prominent ribs, uneven waist, and in severe cases, breathing problems. Treatment depends on the severity and includes observation, bracing in growing children, and surgery for severe curves. Early detection through school screenings is important for optimal outcomes.

Rubella, also known as German measles, is a contagious viral infection caused by the rubella virus. It's generally mild in children and adults, causing symptoms like low-grade fever, sore throat, and a characteristic red rash that starts on the face and spreads downward. However, rubella is particularly dangerous for pregnant women, as infection during pregnancy can cause serious birth defects known as congenital rubella syndrome, including heart defects, cataracts, hearing loss, and developmental delays. The virus spreads through respiratory droplets from coughing and sneezing. Rubella is preventable through vaccination with the MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine, and thanks to widespread vaccination, it has been eliminated in many countries.

Whooping cough, also known as pertussis, is a highly contagious bacterial infection caused by Bordetella pertussis that affects the respiratory system. It's characterized by severe coughing fits followed by a high-pitched 'whoop' sound when breathing in, though this classic symptom may not occur in all cases, especially in infants. The disease progresses through three stages: catarrhal (cold-like symptoms), paroxysmal (severe coughing fits), and convalescent (gradual recovery). Whooping cough is particularly dangerous for infants, who may develop complications like pneumonia, brain damage, or death. It's preventable through vaccination with the DTaP vaccine in children and Tdap booster in adolescents and adults. Treatment involves antibiotics, which are most effective when given early.

Scabies is a contagious skin infestation caused by tiny mites called Sarcoptes scabiei that burrow into the skin and lay eggs. The condition causes intense itching, especially at night, and a red, bumpy rash. Common areas affected include the wrists, elbows, armpits, waist, and between fingers and toes. In infants and young children, the head, neck, palms, and soles may also be affected. Scabies spreads through direct, prolonged skin-to-skin contact and can also spread through sharing bedding, clothing, or towels. Treatment involves prescription topical medications like permethrin cream or oral medications like ivermectin. All household members and close contacts should be treated simultaneously, and personal items should be washed in hot water or isolated.

Anxiety is a normal emotional response to stress, but anxiety disorders involve excessive, persistent worry and fear that interferes with daily activities. Common types include generalized anxiety disorder, panic disorder, social anxiety disorder, and specific phobias. Symptoms can be psychological (excessive worry, restlessness, difficulty concentrating) and physical (rapid heartbeat, sweating, trembling, shortness of breath). Anxiety disorders result from a complex interaction of genetic, environmental, and psychological factors. Treatment typically includes psychotherapy (particularly cognitive-behavioral therapy), medications (antidepressants, anti-anxiety medications), lifestyle modifications, and stress management techniques. With proper treatment, most people with anxiety disorders can manage their symptoms effectively.

Conjunctivitis, commonly known as pink eye, is inflammation of the conjunctiva, the thin membrane that covers the white part of the eye and the inside of the eyelids. It can be caused by viral infections (most common), bacterial infections, allergies, or irritants. Symptoms include redness, itching, burning, excessive tearing, and discharge that may be watery (viral) or thick and yellow-green (bacterial). Viral conjunctivitis is highly contagious and often accompanies cold symptoms, while bacterial conjunctivitis may affect one or both eyes. Allergic conjunctivitis is not contagious and often occurs with other allergy symptoms. Treatment depends on the cause and may include antibiotic drops, antihistamines, or supportive care.

Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition that causes cells to build up rapidly on the skin's surface, forming thick, silvery scales and itchy, dry, red patches. The most common type is plaque psoriasis, but other forms include guttate, inverse, pustular, and erythrodermic psoriasis. It commonly affects the elbows, knees, scalp, and lower back, but can occur anywhere on the body. Psoriasis is not contagious and results from an overactive immune system that speeds up skin cell growth. Triggers include stress, infections, certain medications, and weather changes. Treatment options include topical medications, phototherapy, and systemic medications for severe cases. Many people with psoriasis also develop psoriatic arthritis.

Pancreatitis is inflammation of the pancreas, an organ behind the stomach that produces enzymes for digestion and hormones like insulin. It can be acute (sudden onset) or chronic (long-term). Acute pancreatitis is often caused by gallstones or heavy alcohol use, while chronic pancreatitis is most commonly due to long-term alcohol abuse. Symptoms include severe abdominal pain that may radiate to the back, nausea, vomiting, fever, and rapid pulse. Acute pancreatitis can be life-threatening with complications like infection, bleeding, and organ failure. Chronic pancreatitis can lead to diabetes and digestive problems. Treatment involves pain management, IV fluids, nutritional support, and addressing underlying causes. Severe cases may require hospitalization and surgery.

Chikungunya is a mosquito-borne viral disease transmitted by Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquitoes, the same species that spread dengue and Zika viruses. The name comes from a word meaning 'to walk bent over' in the Makonde language, referring to the stooped posture caused by joint pain. Symptoms typically appear 3-7 days after being bitten by an infected mosquito and include sudden onset of fever, severe joint pain (particularly in hands and feet), headache, muscle pain, and rash. While rarely fatal, the joint pain can be debilitating and may persist for months or years. There's no specific treatment or vaccine; management focuses on symptom relief. Prevention involves controlling mosquito populations and avoiding mosquito bites.

Appendicitis is inflammation of the appendix, a small tube-like structure attached to the first part of the large intestine. It's most commonly caused by blockage of the appendix opening, leading to bacterial infection and inflammation. Classic symptoms include abdominal pain that starts around the navel and shifts to the lower right abdomen, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, and fever. The pain typically worsens with movement, coughing, or deep breathing. Appendicitis is a medical emergency because a ruptured appendix can lead to peritonitis (infection of the abdominal cavity) and sepsis. Diagnosis involves physical examination, blood tests, and imaging studies. Treatment almost always requires surgical removal of the appendix (appendectomy), which can be performed laparoscopically or through open surgery.

Glaucoma is a group of eye diseases that damage the optic nerve, often due to increased pressure inside the eye (intraocular pressure). It's a leading cause of blindness worldwide, particularly in older adults. The most common type is primary open-angle glaucoma, which develops slowly and often without symptoms until significant vision loss occurs. Angle-closure glaucoma is less common but can cause sudden symptoms like severe eye pain, headache, nausea, and blurred vision. Risk factors include age, family history, high eye pressure, thin corneas, and certain medical conditions like diabetes. Regular eye exams are crucial for early detection, as vision loss from glaucoma is irreversible. Treatment includes prescription eye drops, laser therapy, or surgery to lower eye pressure and prevent further damage.

input: Who is the current President of India?
output: As of 2025, the President of India is Droupadi Murmu.

input: CBC Results: WBC 15,000/μL (normal 4,000-11,000), RBC 3.8 million/μL (normal 4.5-5.5), Hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL (normal 12-16), Platelets 450,000/μL (normal 150,000-450,000)
output: This complete blood count shows leukocytosis (elevated white blood cells at 15,000/μL) suggesting possible infection or inflammatory process. The patient has anemia with low RBC count (3.8 million/μL) and hemoglobin (9.2 g/dL), indicating reduced oxygen-carrying capacity. Platelet count is at the upper normal limit. The combination suggests possible chronic disease with secondary infection or hematologic disorder requiring further investigation.

input: Chest X-ray: Bilateral lower lobe infiltrates, cardiomegaly, blunting of costophrenic angles
output: The chest X-ray shows bilateral lower lobe infiltrates indicating pneumonia or pulmonary edema in both lungs. Cardiomegaly suggests heart enlargement, possibly due to heart failure or other cardiac conditions. Blunting of costophrenic angles indicates pleural effusion (fluid around the lungs). This pattern is consistent with congestive heart failure with secondary pneumonia or pulmonary edema, requiring immediate cardiac and pulmonary evaluation.

input: 68-year-old male presents with crushing chest pain radiating to left arm, lasting 45 minutes, associated with nausea, diaphoresis, and shortness of breath. Pain started at rest.
output: This presentation is highly suggestive of acute myocardial infarction (heart attack). The crushing chest pain with left arm radiation, prolonged duration (45 minutes), and associated autonomic symptoms (nausea, sweating) along with dyspnea in an elderly male represent classic signs of ST-elevation MI or unstable angina. The onset at rest indicates unstable coronary syndrome requiring immediate emergency cardiac intervention and ECG evaluation.

input: Patient takes Warfarin 5mg daily, newly prescribed Amoxicillin 500mg TID for dental infection. What are the concerns?
output: This combination presents a significant drug interaction risk. Amoxicillin can potentiate warfarin's anticoagulant effects by disrupting vitamin K-producing gut bacteria and potentially displacing warfarin from protein binding sites. This increases bleeding risk substantially. Monitor INR closely (every 2-3 days initially), consider warfarin dose reduction, educate patient on bleeding signs, and consider alternative antibiotics with less interaction potential like azithromycin if appropriate.

input: Vital Signs: BP 180/110 mmHg, HR 115 bpm, RR 28/min, O2 Sat 88% on room air, Temp 101.8°F
output: These vital signs indicate a critically ill patient with multiple concerning findings: severe hypertension (180/110) suggesting hypertensive crisis, tachycardia (115 bpm), tachypnea (28/min), hypoxemia (88% O2 sat), and fever (101.8°F). This constellation suggests possible sepsis, acute heart failure, or hypertensive emergency with respiratory compromise. Immediate interventions needed include oxygen therapy, blood pressure management, infection workup, and intensive monitoring.

input: 85-year-old female, history of osteoporosis, takes 4 medications including sedatives, recent dizziness episodes, uses walker intermittently, lives alone
output: This patient has multiple high fall risk factors: advanced age (85 years), osteoporosis increasing fracture risk, polypharmacy including sedatives (CNS depression), recent dizziness (balance issues), inconsistent mobility aid use, and social isolation. Fall prevention interventions needed include medication review/reduction, balance assessment, consistent walker use, home safety evaluation, possible supervised living consideration, and bone density optimization.

input: 32-year-old female with RLQ pain, McBurney's point tenderness, nausea, low-grade fever, WBC 12,000, pain migration from periumbilical area
output: Classic presentation of acute appendicitis. Right lower quadrant pain with McBurney's point tenderness, pain migration from periumbilical region, constitutional symptoms (nausea, fever), and mild leukocytosis strongly suggest appendiceal inflammation. This requires urgent surgical evaluation for appendectomy to prevent complications like perforation, abscess formation, or peritonitis. Avoid analgesics until surgical assessment completed.

input: Patient with new diagnosis of Type 2 diabetes, HbA1c 9.8%, started on Metformin 500mg BID, BMI 32, no prior diabetes education
output: Comprehensive discharge planning needed for new diabetic patient. HbA1c of 9.8% indicates poor glucose control requiring intensive management. Discharge needs: diabetes education classes, dietary consultation for carbohydrate counting, blood glucose monitoring supplies and training, foot care education, ophthalmology referral for diabetic eye exam, endocrinology follow-up in 2-4 weeks, primary care in 1 week for medication adjustment, and weight management counseling given BMI 32.

input: ECG: ST elevation in leads II, III, aVF; reciprocal depression in I, aVL; Q waves in III
output: This ECG shows acute inferior wall ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF indicates inferior wall involvement, likely affecting the right coronary artery territory. Reciprocal ST depression in leads I and aVL supports the diagnosis. Q waves in lead III suggest some degree of myocardial necrosis. This requires immediate reperfusion therapy (PCI or thrombolytics), antiplatelet therapy, anticoagulation, and cardiac catheterization.

input: 78-year-old confused patient, MMSE score 18/30, unable to recall recent events, knows name but not date/location, family reports personality changes over 6 months
output: This presentation suggests moderate cognitive impairment, possibly dementia. MMSE score of 18/30 indicates moderate cognitive decline (normal >24). Recent memory loss with preserved personal identity, disorientation to time/place, and progressive personality changes over months are consistent with Alzheimer's disease or other dementia types. Requires comprehensive cognitive assessment, brain imaging, lab workup for reversible causes, medication review, safety evaluation, and family education about dementia progression.

input: 2-year-old with fever 103°F for 3 days, no obvious source, appears toxic, poor feeding, lethargy, petechial rash on trunk
output: This is a potentially serious bacterial infection in a young child. High fever (103°F) for 3 days without obvious source, combined with toxic appearance, poor feeding, lethargy, and especially petechial rash raises concern for bacteremia or meningitis. Immediate evaluation needed: blood cultures, urine culture, lumbar puncture if indicated, complete blood count, and empirical broad-spectrum antibiotics pending culture results. Consider admission for observation and IV antibiotics.

input: Post-surgical wound day 5: 3cm dehiscence, purulent drainage, surrounding erythema extending 2cm, wound edges not approximated, patient febrile
output: This describes a complicated surgical site infection with wound dehiscence. Signs include wound separation (3cm dehiscence), purulent drainage indicating bacterial infection, surrounding cellulitis (erythema extending 2cm), loss of wound integrity, and systemic signs (fever). Management requires wound cultures, broad-spectrum antibiotics, surgical consultation for possible debridement or revision, wound care with frequent dressing changes, and consideration of negative pressure wound therapy.

input: PFTs: FEV1 45% predicted, FVC 78% predicted, FEV1/FVC ratio 58%, post-bronchodilator FEV1 improved 8%
output: These pulmonary function tests indicate moderate obstructive lung disease. Reduced FEV1 (45% predicted) with preserved FVC (78%) and low FEV1/FVC ratio (58%, normal >70%) confirms airway obstruction. The minimal bronchodilator response (8% improvement) suggests fixed airway obstruction consistent with COPD rather than reversible asthma. Staging indicates GOLD Grade 3 (moderate-severe) COPD requiring bronchodilator therapy, pulmonary rehabilitation, smoking cessation if applicable, and vaccination.

input: 78-year-old with known systolic heart failure, EF 25%, presents with worsening dyspnea, orthopnea, bilateral lower extremity edema, weight gain 8 lbs in 3 days, JVD, S3 gallop
output: This presentation indicates acute decompensated heart failure exacerbation. Clinical signs include worsening dyspnea, orthopnea (positional breathlessness), significant weight gain (8 lbs/3 days suggesting fluid retention), jugular venous distension, and S3 gallop indicating volume overload. With known reduced EF (25%), requires immediate management: chest X-ray for pulmonary edema, BNP or NT-proBNP, comprehensive metabolic panel, IV diuretics (furosemide), ACE inhibitor optimization when stable, beta-blocker continuation, daily weights, strict fluid/sodium restriction, and cardiology consultation for medication adjustment.

input: Type 1 diabetic, 22-year-old, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, Kussmaul respirations, fruity breath odor, glucose 485 mg/dL, pH 7.1, bicarbonate 8 mEq/L, ketones 4+
output: Classic presentation of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) with metabolic acidosis triad: hyperglycemia (485 mg/dL), acidosis (pH 7.1), and ketosis (4+). Kussmaul respirations and fruity breath (acetone) are pathognomonic signs. Severe acidosis (bicarbonate 8) indicates significant metabolic derangement. Immediate management requires: IV fluid resuscitation, insulin infusion protocol, electrolyte monitoring and replacement (especially potassium), identification of precipitating cause (infection, medication noncompliance), arterial blood gases monitoring, and ICU-level care. Avoid bicarbonate unless pH <6.9. Monitor for cerebral edema, especially in young patients.

input: 55-year-old smoker, FEV1 1.8L (55% predicted), FVC 3.2L (70% predicted), FEV1/FVC ratio 0.56, DLCO 65% predicted, chronic cough and dyspnea
output: Pulmonary function tests confirm moderate COPD (GOLD Stage 2). Reduced FEV1 (55% predicted) with FEV1/FVC ratio <0.70 (0.56) indicates airflow obstruction. Preserved FVC (70%) suggests primarily emphysematous pattern. Reduced DLCO (65%) indicates impaired gas exchange consistent with emphysema. Clinical correlation with smoking history and symptoms supports COPD diagnosis. Management includes: smoking cessation counseling with pharmacotherapy, bronchodilator therapy (LABA/LAMA combination), pulmonary rehabilitation, pneumococcal and influenza vaccination, and assessment for oxygen therapy if hypoxemic.

input: 45-year-old male, severe epigastric pain radiating to back, nausea, vomiting, history of gallstones, lipase 850 U/L (normal 10-140), CT shows pancreatic inflammation
output: Acute pancreatitis diagnosis confirmed by classic triad: characteristic abdominal pain (epigastric radiating to back), elevated pancreatic enzymes (lipase 850, >3x normal), and imaging findings. Gallstone etiology likely given history. Severity assessment needed using Ranson criteria or APACHE II score. Management includes: NPO initially, aggressive IV hydration, pain control (avoid morphine - use fentanyl or hydromorphone), monitor for complications (pseudocyst, necrosis, ARDS), ERCP consideration if concurrent cholangitis, and surgical consultation for gallstone pancreatitis. Nutritional support if prolonged course.

input: 62-year-old with known Graves' disease, fever 104°F, heart rate 155, blood pressure 90/60, altered mental status, diaphoresis, recent iodine contrast exposure
output: Thyroid storm (hyperthyroid crisis) - life-threatening endocrine emergency. Combination of hyperthermia (104°F), tachycardia (155), hypotension, altered mental status, and known Graves' disease with recent iodine exposure (precipitant) confirms diagnosis. Requires immediate ICU management: aggressive cooling measures, IV fluids for hypotension, beta-blockade for cardiovascular symptoms, antithyroid medications (methimazole), iodine (after antithyroid drugs), corticosteroids for adrenal insufficiency, broad-spectrum antibiotics pending cultures, and treatment of precipitating factors. Mortality high without prompt treatment.

input: 25-year-old after tibia fracture, severe pain out of proportion to injury, pain with passive stretch of toes, tense swelling of anterior compartment, diminished sensation between first and second toes
output: Acute compartment syndrome of the anterior compartment - orthopedic emergency requiring immediate fasciotomy. Classic findings include: pain out of proportion to injury, pain with passive stretch (most sensitive sign), tense compartment swelling, and neurologic deficits (diminished sensation in deep peroneal nerve distribution). Compartment pressure measurement >30 mmHg or within 30 mmHg of diastolic pressure confirms diagnosis. Immediate surgical fasciotomy required to prevent permanent muscle/nerve damage. Do not delay for imaging or further testing. Orthopedic surgery consultation emergently. Pulses may remain present until late stages.

input: ABG results: pH 7.25, PCO2 55 mmHg, HCO3 22 mEq/L, PO2 65 mmHg, oxygen saturation 90%, patient with COPD exacerbation
output: Arterial blood gas shows respiratory acidosis with hypoxemia. pH 7.25 (acidic), elevated PCO2 (55 mmHg, normal 35-45) indicates respiratory acidosis with inadequate ventilation. Normal bicarbonate (22 mEq/L) suggests acute process without metabolic compensation. Hypoxemia evident with PO2 65 mmHg and O2 sat 90%. Consistent with COPD exacerbation causing acute respiratory failure. Management requires: supplemental oxygen (target 88-92% in COPD), bronchodilators, systemic corticosteroids, non-invasive ventilation consideration if persistent hypercapnia, and careful monitoring for CO2 narcosis. Avoid over-oxygenation in COPD patients.

input: Post-op day 3 abdominal surgery, fever 101.8°F, tachycardia 110, surgical site erythema and warmth, purulent drainage from incision, white blood cell count 16,000
output: Postoperative surgical site infection (SSI) with systemic inflammatory response. Fever, tachycardia, elevated WBC (16,000), and local signs of infection (erythema, warmth, purulent drainage) indicate wound infection with possible sepsis. Post-operative day 3 timing is typical for bacterial SSI development. Requires immediate management: wound cultures, blood cultures, broad-spectrum antibiotics covering gram-positive organisms and anaerobes, wound debridement/drainage, surgical consultation for wound exploration, fluid resuscitation if septic, and close monitoring for progression to severe sepsis or septic shock.

input: 68-year-old presents with severe unilateral eye pain, headache, nausea, vomiting, halos around lights, visual acuity decreased, pupil mid-dilated and non-reactive, corneal edema
output: Acute angle-closure glaucoma - ophthalmologic emergency requiring immediate treatment. Classic presentation includes severe unilateral eye pain, headache, nausea/vomiting (from elevated IOP), visual symptoms (halos, decreased acuity), and examination findings of mid-dilated non-reactive pupil and corneal edema. Intraocular pressure typically >40 mmHg. Immediate management: topical beta-blocker (timolol), alpha-agonist (brimonidine), carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (acetazolamide), topical steroid, and emergent ophthalmology consultation for laser peripheral iridotomy. Delay can result in permanent vision loss.

input: 30-year-old develops urticaria, angioedema, wheezing, and hypotension 15 minutes after antibiotic injection, patient reports throat tightness and difficulty swallowing
output: Anaphylactic reaction - life-threatening systemic allergic response requiring immediate treatment. Multi-system involvement with cutaneous (urticaria, angioedema), respiratory (wheezing, throat tightness), and cardiovascular (hypotension) symptoms within minutes of antigen exposure confirms diagnosis. Immediate management: epinephrine 0.3-0.5mg IM (anterolateral thigh), high-flow oxygen, IV access with fluid resuscitation, H1 antihistamine (diphenhydramine), H2 antihistamine (ranitidine), corticosteroids (methylprednisolone), nebulized albuterol for bronchospasm. Monitor for biphasic reaction. Epinephrine auto-injector prescription and allergy alert bracelet recommended.

input: 45-year-old with acute onset knee pain, swelling, warmth, limited range of motion, fever 102°F, synovial fluid analysis: WBC 85,000/μL with 95% neutrophils, gram-positive cocci seen
output: Septic arthritis confirmed by clinical presentation and synovial fluid analysis. Acute monoarticular arthritis with fever, joint effusion, and synovial fluid showing >50,000 WBC/μL with neutrophil predominance and bacteria on Gram stain establishes diagnosis. Staphylococcus aureus likely pathogen based on gram-positive cocci. Requires immediate management: orthopedic consultation for surgical drainage, IV antibiotics (vancomycin pending cultures), blood cultures, joint immobilization, pain control, and monitoring for complications. Delay in treatment can result in joint destruction and osteomyelitis. Repeat aspiration may be needed if poor clinical response.

input: Echo results: EF 35%, moderate mitral regurgitation, left atrial enlargement, elevated pulmonary pressures (45 mmHg), regional wall motion abnormalities in LAD territory
output: Echocardiogram shows systolic heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) and secondary mitral regurgitation. EF 35% indicates moderate systolic dysfunction, likely from prior myocardial infarction given LAD territory wall motion abnormalities. Moderate mitral regurgitation is likely functional/secondary to left ventricular dysfunction. Left atrial enlargement and elevated pulmonary pressures (45 mmHg) indicate chronic elevation of left heart filling pressures. Management requires: ACE inhibitor/ARB, beta-blocker, aldosterone antagonist if appropriate, diuretics for volume management, statin therapy, cardiac catheterization consideration for revascularization, and mitral valve evaluation if regurgitation severe.

input: Creatinine increased from 1.2 to 3.5 mg/dL over 48 hours, BUN 65, oliguria <400 mL/day, recent contrast exposure, taking NSAIDs, blood pressure 95/60
output: Acute kidney injury (AKI) Stage 3 with multiple potential etiologies. Creatinine increase >3x baseline (1.2 to 3.5) with oliguria indicates severe AKI. Recent contrast exposure suggests contrast-induced nephropathy, NSAIDs indicate possible acute tubular necrosis, and hypotension suggests prerenal azotemia. Requires immediate management: discontinue nephrotoxic medications (NSAIDs), IV fluid resuscitation if prerenal, urinalysis and microscopy, renal ultrasound to exclude obstruction, nephrology consultation, electrolyte monitoring (especially potassium), and consideration of renal replacement therapy if severe complications develop. Monitor for fluid overload and electrolyte abnormalities.

input: 22-year-old college student, fever 103°F, severe headache, neck stiffness, photophobia, altered mental status, petechial rash on extremities, Kernig's sign positive
output: Clinical presentation highly suggestive of bacterial meningitis, possibly meningococcal given petechial rash and college setting. Classic triad of fever, headache, and neck stiffness with positive meningeal signs (Kernig's sign) and altered mental status indicates CNS infection. Petechial rash suggests Neisseria meningitidis. Requires immediate management: blood cultures, lumbar puncture (unless contraindicated), empiric antibiotics (ceftriaxone plus vancomycin), dexamethasone if pneumococcal suspected, isolation precautions, close contact prophylaxis, and ICU monitoring for complications including shock, seizures, and increased intracranial pressure. Time-critical diagnosis with high mortality if delayed.

input: 65-year-old vegetarian, fatigue, weakness, paresthesias in hands and feet, pale conjunctiva, glossitis, MCV 115 fL, B12 level 150 pg/mL (normal 300-900)
output: Vitamin B12 deficiency with megaloblastic anemia and neurologic symptoms. Low B12 level (150 pg/mL) with macrocytic anemia (MCV 115 fL) confirms deficiency. Clinical features of fatigue, weakness, paresthesias, pallor, and glossitis are consistent. Vegetarian diet is common cause due to B12 found primarily in animal products. Requires evaluation for pernicious anemia (intrinsic factor antibodies, methylmalonic acid), immediate B12 replacement (cyanocobalamin injections initially, then oral maintenance), folate supplementation, monitoring of neurologic symptoms, and dietary counseling. Neurologic damage may be irreversible if treatment delayed.

input: 72-year-old with history of gallstones, presents with fever 101.5°F, jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, altered mental status, total bilirubin 8.5 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase 450 U/L
output: Acute cholangitis (Charcot's triad plus altered mental status = Reynolds pentad) - biliary emergency requiring immediate intervention. Classic presentation with fever, jaundice, RUQ pain, plus altered mental status and laboratory evidence of cholestasis (elevated bilirubin 8.5, alkaline phosphatase 450) confirms diagnosis. Common bile duct obstruction likely from gallstone. Requires immediate management: broad-spectrum antibiotics (piperacillin-tazobactam or ciprofloxacin plus metronidazole), ERCP with sphincterotomy and stone extraction, IV fluids, pain control, and surgical consultation for cholecystectomy. Delay in biliary decompression can lead to septic shock and death.

input: Exercise stress test: achieved 85% maximum predicted heart rate, developed chest pain at peak exercise, 2mm ST depression in leads V4-V6, exercise capacity 6 METs, blood pressure response normal
output: Positive exercise stress test indicating significant coronary artery disease. Achievement of 85% maximum predicted heart rate ensures adequate stress, but development of typical chest pain with 2mm ST depression in lateral leads (V4-V6) indicates exercise-induced ischemia, likely in left circumflex or diagonal artery territory. Reduced exercise capacity (6 METs) suggests functional impairment. Normal blood pressure response excludes severe left main disease. Requires cardiology referral for coronary angiography, antiplatelet therapy (aspirin), beta-blocker, statin, and risk factor modification. Consider stress imaging if non-diagnostic ECG changes.

input: 45-year-old post-appendectomy day 5, severe diffuse abdominal pain, fever 102°F, tachycardia, abdominal distension, absent bowel sounds, rebound tenderness, WBC 18,000
output: Clinical presentation consistent with peritonitis, likely from anastomotic leak or perforation. Post-operative day 5 timing, diffuse severe abdominal pain, fever, tachycardia, absent bowel sounds, and peritoneal signs (rebound tenderness) with leukocytosis (18,000) indicate intra-abdominal infection. Requires immediate management: NPO status, nasogastric decompression, IV fluid resuscitation, broad-spectrum antibiotics covering gram-negative and anaerobic organisms, CT abdomen/pelvis with contrast to identify source, and emergent surgical consultation for exploratory laparotomy. Delay can lead to septic shock and multi-organ failure.

input: Type 1 diabetic on insulin, found unconscious, diaphoretic, tachycardic, glucose 28 mg/dL, responds to IV dextrose with improved mental status
output: Severe hypoglycemia with neuroglycopenia requiring immediate treatment. Glucose 28 mg/dL with unconsciousness, diaphoresis, and tachycardia represents severe hypoglycemic episode with sympathetic and neuroglycopenic symptoms. Response to IV dextrose confirms hypoglycemia as cause. Investigate precipitating factors: medication error, missed meals, increased exercise, alcohol use, or insulin overdose. Management includes: continuous glucose monitoring, frequent blood glucose checks, glucagon education for family, review of insulin regimen and carbohydrate counting, identification of hypoglycemia unawareness, and diabetes education reinforcement. Consider reducing insulin doses temporarily.

input: 75-year-old presents with palpitations, shortness of breath, heart rate 155 irregular, blood pressure 110/70, ECG shows atrial fibrillation, no chest pain, stable vital signs
output: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) requiring rate control and anticoagulation consideration. Heart rate 155 with irregular rhythm confirms rapid AF. Hemodynamically stable (BP 110/70, no chest pain) allows for pharmacologic rate control rather than emergent cardioversion. Requires immediate management: rate control with beta-blocker (metoprolol) or calcium channel blocker (diltiazem), anticoagulation assessment using CHA2DS2-VASc score, thyroid function tests, electrolyte correction, echocardiogram to assess left atrial size and function, and cardiology consultation for rhythm management strategy. Monitor for hemodynamic compromise requiring urgent cardioversion.

input: 28-year-old with known asthma, increased wheezing, dyspnea, chest tightness, peak flow 40% of personal best, accessory muscle use, oxygen saturation 91% on room air
output: Moderate to severe acute asthma exacerbation based on clinical presentation and peak flow measurement. Peak flow 40% of personal best with accessory muscle use and hypoxemia (O2 sat 91%) indicates significant airway obstruction. Requires immediate bronchodilator therapy: high-dose nebulized albuterol and ipratropium, systemic corticosteroids (prednisolone 40-50mg), supplemental oxygen to maintain saturation >90%, monitor response with serial peak flows and clinical assessment. Consider IV magnesium if severe, and prepare for intubation if signs of respiratory failure develop. Discharge planning includes inhaler technique review and asthma action plan.

input: Mammography: BIRADS 4 lesion in right breast upper outer quadrant, 1.2 cm irregular mass with spiculated margins, associated microcalcifications, architectural distortion present
output: Mammography findings highly suspicious for malignancy requiring immediate biopsy. BIRADS 4 classification indicates suspicious abnormality with 2-95% probability of malignancy. Irregular mass with spiculated margins, associated microcalcifications, and architectural distortion are classic features of invasive breast carcinoma. Requires urgent referral to breast surgeon or interventional radiologist for core needle biopsy, bilateral breast MRI consideration for staging if malignant, genetic counseling assessment, and multidisciplinary team coordination. Patient counseling about findings and next steps essential. Avoid delay in tissue diagnosis.

input: 68-year-old with melena for 2 days, hemoglobin drop from 12 to 8 g/dL, heart rate 105, blood pressure 100/65, history of NSAIDs use, epigastric discomfort
output: Upper gastrointestinal bleeding likely from peptic ulcer disease secondary to NSAID use. Melena indicates upper GI source, significant hemoglobin drop (12 to 8 g/dL) shows substantial blood loss, mild tachycardia and hypotension suggest hypovolemia. Epigastric discomfort with NSAID history points to peptic ulcer. Requires immediate management: two large-bore IV access, type and crossmatch blood, complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, coagulation studies, PPI therapy (pantoprazole), NPO status, and emergent upper endoscopy for diagnosis and therapeutic intervention. Discontinue NSAIDs and H. pylori testing indicated.

input: 19-year-old athlete, brief loss of consciousness during basketball practice, witnessed tonic-clonic movements lasting 10 seconds, rapid recovery, family history of sudden cardiac death at young age
output: Exercise-induced syncope in young athlete with family history of sudden cardiac death raises concern for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy or arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy. Brief tonic-clonic movements during syncope can occur with cerebral hypoperfusion and don't necessarily indicate seizure. Requires comprehensive cardiac evaluation: 12-lead ECG, echocardiogram, exercise stress test, 24-hour Holter monitor, and cardiology consultation. Consider genetic testing and family screening. Immediate activity restriction until cardiac evaluation complete. Rule out long QT syndrome, Brugada syndrome, and other inherited cardiomyopathies. Sudden cardiac death prevention is priority.

input: Chronic kidney disease patient, potassium 6.8 mEq/L, peaked T waves on ECG, muscle weakness, paresthesias, taking ACE inhibitor and spironolactone
output: Severe hyperkalemia (6.8 mEq/L) with ECG changes indicating cardiac toxicity requiring immediate treatment. Peaked T waves are early sign of hyperkalemia-induced cardiac conduction abnormalities. Muscle weakness and paresthesias indicate neuromuscular effects. CKD with ACE inhibitor and spironolactone are contributing factors. Immediate management: continuous cardiac monitoring, calcium gluconate for cardioprotection, insulin with dextrose to shift potassium intracellularly, sodium bicarbonate if acidotic, discontinue potassium-sparing medications, low-potassium diet, and consider dialysis if severe or refractory. Monitor for progression to cardiac arrest.

input: Day 7 acute pancreatitis, persistent fever, leukocytosis, abdominal pain, CT shows 6 cm fluid collection in lesser sac, patient unable to tolerate oral intake
output: Acute pancreatitis complicated by pancreatic pseudocyst formation and possible infection. Persistent fever and leukocytosis beyond day 7 with CT showing fluid collection (6 cm) suggests infected pseudocyst or pancreatic necrosis. Inability to tolerate oral intake indicates ongoing pancreatic inflammation. Requires fine-needle aspiration of fluid collection for culture and Gram stain, IV antibiotics if infected (imipenem or fluoroquinolone plus metronidazole), nutritional support (enteral preferred over parenteral), pain management, and gastroenterology/surgery consultation for drainage procedure if infected or symptomatic. Monitor for hemorrhage, rupture, or biliary obstruction.

input: 3 cm thyroid nodule, solid and hypoechoic on ultrasound, irregular borders, microcalcifications present, TSH normal, FNA biopsy shows follicular neoplasm
output: Thyroid nodule with suspicious sonographic features and indeterminate cytology requiring surgical evaluation. Size >3 cm, solid hypoechoic appearance, irregular borders, and microcalcifications are suspicious for malignancy. Follicular neoplasm on FNA is indeterminate (Bethesda IV) with 15-30% malignancy risk - cannot distinguish follicular adenoma from carcinoma on cytology alone. Normal TSH excludes hyperfunctioning nodule. Requires endocrine surgery consultation for diagnostic thyroid lobectomy, molecular testing consideration (Afirma, ThyroSeq), completion thyroidectomy if malignant on final pathology, and preoperative vocal cord assessment. Avoid repeat FNA for follicular neoplasm diagnosis.

input: 55-year-old sudden onset severe vertigo, nausea, vomiting, unable to walk, horizontal nystagmus that changes direction with gaze, no hearing loss, HINTS exam suggests central cause
output: Central vertigo likely from posterior circulation stroke (vertebrobasilar system) based on HINTS examination findings. Sudden onset severe vertigo with direction-changing nystagmus and abnormal HINTS exam (Head Impulse, Nystagmus, Test of Skew) suggests central rather than peripheral etiology. Absence of hearing loss helps exclude acoustic neuroma. Requires immediate evaluation: brain MRI with DWI to detect posterior circulation infarct, CTA head/neck for vascular assessment, neurologic consultation, blood pressure management, antiplatelet therapy if stroke confirmed, and admission for stroke protocol. Time-sensitive diagnosis as brainstem strokes can rapidly progress.

input: 22-year-old found unconscious, pinpoint pupils, respiratory depression (rate 8/min), shallow breathing, suspected opioid overdose, drug paraphernalia at scene
output: Opioid overdose with classic triad: altered mental status (unconscious), pinpoint pupils (miosis), and respiratory depression.
