Respiratory rate 8/min with shallow breathing indicates life-threatening hypoventilation requiring immediate intervention. Administer naloxone (Narcan) 0.4-2mg IV/IM/intranasal, provide bag-mask ventilation if needed, establish IV access, continuous monitoring, repeat naloxone doses as needed (short half-life), observe for 2-4 hours for re-narcotization, toxicology screen, and address underlying substance use disorder with addiction medicine consultation. Consider fentanyl involvement requiring higher naloxone doses. Supportive care and airway management priority.

input: 34 weeks pregnant, blood pressure 170/110, proteinuria 3+, severe headache, visual changes, epigastric pain, platelets 85,000, elevated liver enzymes
output: Preeclampsia with severe features requiring immediate delivery planning. Severe hypertension (170/110), proteinuria (3+), neurologic symptoms (headache, visual changes), epigastric pain suggesting hepatic involvement, thrombocytopenia (85,000), and elevated liver enzymes indicate severe preeclampsia/HELLP syndrome. At 34 weeks, requires immediate obstetric consultation, magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis, antihypertensive therapy (labetalol or hydralazine), corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity, continuous fetal monitoring, and delivery planning. Maternal stabilization followed by delivery is definitive treatment. Monitor for eclampsia, placental abruption, and other complications.

input: 68-year-old sudden onset severe left leg pain, leg pale and cold, absent dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, decreased sensation, history of atrial fibrillation not on anticoagulation
output: Acute limb ischemia (Class IIa - marginally threatened) requiring emergency revascularization. Classic 6 P's present: Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Paresthesias, with history suggesting embolic source (atrial fibrillation). Decreased sensation indicates threatened limb viability. Requires immediate vascular surgery consultation, heparin anticoagulation, CTA lower extremity for anatomic planning, pain control, and emergent thrombectomy/embolectomy within 6 hours to prevent limb loss. Consider catheter-directed thrombolysis if presentation <14 days. Post-revascularization monitoring for reperfusion injury and compartment syndrome essential. Initiate anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation stroke prevention.

input: Lumbar puncture results: opening pressure 28 cm H2O, WBC 150/μL (90% lymphocytes), protein 85 mg/dL, glucose 45 mg/dL (serum glucose 90 mg/dL), Gram stain negative
output: CSF analysis suggests viral meningitis or early bacterial meningitis. Elevated opening pressure (28 cm H2O, normal <20), moderate pleocytosis (150 WBC/μL) with lymphocytic predominance (90%), elevated protein (85 mg/dL), and low-normal glucose ratio (CSF:serum 0.5) indicate CNS inflammation. Negative Gram stain doesn't exclude bacterial meningitis early in course. Requires viral PCR panel (HSV, enterovirus, VZV), bacterial cultures, consider empiric acyclovir if HSV encephalitis suspected, supportive care, and close monitoring for clinical deterioration. If bacterial meningitis suspected despite lymphocytic predominance, maintain empiric antibiotics until cultures negative.

input: 58-year-old male, 2 hours of crushing substernal chest pain, diaphoresis, nausea, pain radiates to left arm, ECG shows 3mm ST elevation in leads II, III, aVF
output: Acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) in inferior wall distribution requiring immediate reperfusion therapy. Classic presentation with crushing chest pain, diaphoresis, radiation to left arm, and ST elevations in inferior leads (II, III, aVF) indicate RCA or LCX occlusion. Within 2 hours of symptom onset - optimal window for primary PCI. Immediate management: aspirin 325mg, clopidogrel loading dose, atorvastatin, metoprolol (if no contraindications), heparin, and emergent cardiac catheterization for primary PCI. Consider right-sided ECG for RV involvement if inferior STEMI. Door-to-balloon time goal <90 minutes. Monitor for complications including cardiogenic shock and arrhythmias.

input: 62-year-old left lower quadrant pain, fever 101°F, nausea, change in bowel habits, CT shows sigmoid wall thickening and fat stranding, no perforation or abscess
output: Uncomplicated acute diverticulitis based on clinical presentation and CT findings. Left lower quadrant pain, fever, and CT showing sigmoid wall thickening with fat stranding (no perforation/abscess) indicates localized inflammatory process. Uncomplicated disease can be managed outpatient if stable. Treatment includes: clear liquid diet initially, oral antibiotics (ciprofloxacin plus metronidazole or amoxicillin-clavulanate), pain management, follow-up in 48-72 hours, and colonoscopy 6-8 weeks after resolution to exclude malignancy. Admission indicated if unable to tolerate oral intake, severe pain, or signs of complications. Dietary counseling regarding fiber intake for prevention.
